string: ACT I
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Flourish of trumpets: then hautboys. Enter KING  HENRY VI, GLOUCESTER, SALISBURY, WARWICK, and  CARDINAL, on the one side; QUEEN MARGARET, SUFFOLK, YORK, SOMERSET, and BUCKINGHAM, on the other
SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As by your high imperial majesty
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: I had in charge at my depart for France,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: As procurator to your excellence,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: To marry Princess Margaret for your grace,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: So, in the famous ancient city, Tours,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: In presence of the Kings of France and Sicil,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: The Dukes of Orleans, Calaber, Bretagne and Alencon,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Seven earls, twelve barons and twenty reverend bishops,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: I have perform'd my task and was espoused:
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: And humbly now upon my bended knee,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: In sight of England and her lordly peers,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Deliver up my title in the queen
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: To your most gracious hands, that are the substance
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Of that great shadow I did represent;
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: The happiest gift that ever marquess gave,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: The fairest queen that ever king received.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Suffolk, arise. Welcome, Queen Margaret:
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: I can express no kinder sign of love
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Than this kind kiss. O Lord, that lends me life,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Lend me a heart replete with thankfulness!
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: For thou hast given me in this beauteous face
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: A world of earthly blessings to my soul,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: If sympathy of love unite our thoughts.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: QUEEN MARGARET
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: Great King of England and my gracious lord,
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: The mutual conference that my mind hath had,
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: By day, by night, waking and in my dreams,
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: In courtly company or at my beads,
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: With you, mine alder-liefest sovereign,
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: Makes me the bolder to salute my king
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: With ruder terms, such as my wit affords
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: And over-joy of heart doth minister.
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Her sight did ravish; but her grace in speech,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Her words y-clad with wisdom's majesty,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Makes me from wondering fall to weeping joys;
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Such is the fulness of my heart's content.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Lords, with one cheerful voice welcome my love.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: ALL
speaker: ALL

string: [Kneeling]  Long live Queen Margaret, England's
speaker: ALL

string: happiness!
speaker: ALL

string: QUEEN MARGARET
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: We thank you all.
speaker: QUEEN MARGARET

string: Flourish
SUFFOLK
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: My lord protector, so it please your grace,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Here are the articles of contracted peace
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: Between our sovereign and the French king Charles,
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: For eighteen months concluded by consent.
speaker: SUFFOLK

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: [Reads]  'Imprimis, it is agreed between the French
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: king Charles, and William de la Pole, Marquess of
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Suffolk, ambassador for Henry King of England, that
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: the said Henry shall espouse the Lady Margaret,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: daughter unto Reignier King of Naples, Sicilia and
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Jerusalem, and crown her Queen of England ere the
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: thirtieth of May next ensuing. Item, that the duchy
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: of Anjou and the county of Maine shall be released
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: and delivered to the king her father'--
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Lets the paper fall
KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Uncle, how now!
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Pardon me, gracious lord;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Some sudden qualm hath struck me at the heart
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And dimm'd mine eyes, that I can read no further.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Uncle of Winchester, I pray, read on.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: CARDINAL
speaker: CARDINAL

string: [Reads]  'Item, It is further agreed between them,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: that the duchies of Anjou and Maine shall be
speaker: CARDINAL

string: released and delivered over to the king her father,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: and she sent over of the King of England's own
speaker: CARDINAL

string: proper cost and charges, without having any dowry.'
speaker: CARDINAL

string: KING HENRY VI
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: They please us well. Lord marquess, kneel down:
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: We here create thee the first duke of Suffolk,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: And gird thee with the sword. Cousin of York,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: We here discharge your grace from being regent
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: I' the parts of France, till term of eighteen months
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Be full expired. Thanks, uncle Winchester,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Gloucester, York, Buckingham, Somerset,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Salisbury, and Warwick;
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: We thank you all for the great favour done,
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: In entertainment to my princely queen.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Come, let us in, and with all speed provide
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: To see her coronation be perform'd.
speaker: KING HENRY VI

string: Exeunt KING HENRY VI, QUEEN MARGARET, and SUFFOLK
GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Brave peers of England, pillars of the state,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To you Duke Humphrey must unload his grief,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Your grief, the common grief of all the land.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: What! did my brother Henry spend his youth,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: His valour, coin and people, in the wars?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Did he so often lodge in open field,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: In winter's cold and summer's parching heat,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To conquer France, his true inheritance?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And did my brother Bedford toil his wits,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To keep by policy what Henry got?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Have you yourselves, Somerset, Buckingham,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Brave York, Salisbury, and victorious Warwick,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Received deep scars in France and Normandy?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Or hath mine uncle Beaufort and myself,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: With all the learned council of the realm,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Studied so long, sat in the council-house
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Early and late, debating to and fro
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: How France and Frenchmen might be kept in awe,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And had his highness in his infancy
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Crowned in Paris in despite of foes?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And shall these labours and these honours die?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Shall Henry's conquest, Bedford's vigilance,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Your deeds of war and all our counsel die?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: O peers of England, shameful is this league!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Fatal this marriage, cancelling your fame,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Blotting your names from books of memory,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Razing the characters of your renown,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Defacing monuments of conquer'd France,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Undoing all, as all had never been!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CARDINAL
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Nephew, what means this passionate discourse,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: This peroration with such circumstance?
speaker: CARDINAL

string: For France, 'tis ours; and we will keep it still.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Ay, uncle, we will keep it, if we can;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: But now it is impossible we should:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Suffolk, the new-made duke that rules the roast,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Hath given the duchy of Anjou and Maine
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Unto the poor King Reignier, whose large style
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Agrees not with the leanness of his purse.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Now, by the death of Him that died for all,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: These counties were the keys of Normandy.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: But wherefore weeps Warwick, my valiant son?
speaker: SALISBURY

string: WARWICK
speaker: WARWICK

string: For grief that they are past recovery:
speaker: WARWICK

string: For, were there hope to conquer them again,
speaker: WARWICK

string: My sword should shed hot blood, mine eyes no tears.
speaker: WARWICK

string: Anjou and Maine! myself did win them both;
speaker: WARWICK

string: Those provinces these arms of mine did conquer:
speaker: WARWICK

string: And are the cities, that I got with wounds,
speaker: WARWICK

string: Delivered up again with peaceful words?
speaker: WARWICK

string: Mort Dieu!
speaker: WARWICK

string: YORK
speaker: YORK

string: For Suffolk's duke, may he be suffocate,
speaker: YORK

string: That dims the honour of this warlike isle!
speaker: YORK

string: France should have torn and rent my very heart,
speaker: YORK

string: Before I would have yielded to this league.
speaker: YORK

string: I never read but England's kings have had
speaker: YORK

string: Large sums of gold and dowries with their wives:
speaker: YORK

string: And our King Henry gives away his own,
speaker: YORK

string: To match with her that brings no vantages.
speaker: YORK

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: A proper jest, and never heard before,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: That Suffolk should demand a whole fifteenth
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: For costs and charges in transporting her!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: She should have stayed in France and starved
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: in France, Before--
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: CARDINAL
speaker: CARDINAL

string: My Lord of Gloucester, now ye grow too hot:
speaker: CARDINAL

string: It was the pleasure of my lord the King.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: My Lord of Winchester, I know your mind;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: 'Tis not my speeches that you do mislike,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: But 'tis my presence that doth trouble ye.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Rancour will out: proud prelate, in thy face
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I see thy fury: if I longer stay,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: We shall begin our ancient bickerings.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Lordings, farewell; and say, when I am gone,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: I prophesied France will be lost ere long.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Exit
CARDINAL
speaker: CARDINAL

string: So, there goes our protector in a rage.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: 'Tis known to you he is mine enemy,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Nay, more, an enemy unto you all,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: And no great friend, I fear me, to the king.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Consider, lords, he is the next of blood,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: And heir apparent to the English crown:
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Had Henry got an empire by his marriage,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: And all the wealthy kingdoms of the west,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: There's reason he should be displeased at it.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Look to it, lords! let not his smoothing words
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Bewitch your hearts; be wise and circumspect.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: What though the common people favour him,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Calling him 'Humphrey, the good Duke of
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Gloucester,'
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Clapping their hands, and crying with loud voice,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: 'Jesu maintain your royal excellence!'
speaker: CARDINAL

string: With 'God preserve the good Duke Humphrey!'
speaker: CARDINAL

string: I fear me, lords, for all this flattering gloss,
speaker: CARDINAL

string: He will be found a dangerous protector.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: BUCKINGHAM
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: Why should he, then, protect our sovereign,
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: He being of age to govern of himself?
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: Cousin of Somerset, join you with me,
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: And all together, with the Duke of Suffolk,
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: We'll quickly hoise Duke Humphrey from his seat.
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: CARDINAL
speaker: CARDINAL

string: This weighty business will not brook delay:
speaker: CARDINAL

string: I'll to the Duke of Suffolk presently.
speaker: CARDINAL

string: Exit
SOMERSET
speaker: SOMERSET

string: Cousin of Buckingham, though Humphrey's pride
speaker: SOMERSET

string: And greatness of his place be grief to us,
speaker: SOMERSET

string: Yet let us watch the haughty cardinal:
speaker: SOMERSET

string: His insolence is more intolerable
speaker: SOMERSET

string: Than all the princes in the land beside:
speaker: SOMERSET

string: If Gloucester be displaced, he'll be protector.
speaker: SOMERSET

string: BUCKINGHAM
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: Or thou or I, Somerset, will be protector,
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: Despite Duke Humphrey or the cardinal.
speaker: BUCKINGHAM

string: Exeunt BUCKINGHAM and SOMERSET
SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Pride went before, ambition follows him.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: While these do labour for their own preferment,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Behoves it us to labour for the realm.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: I never saw but Humphrey Duke of Gloucester
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Did bear him like a noble gentleman.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Oft have I seen the haughty cardinal,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: More like a soldier than a man o' the church,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: As stout and proud as he were lord of all,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Swear like a ruffian and demean himself
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Unlike the ruler of a commonweal.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Warwick, my son, the comfort of my age,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Thy deeds, thy plainness and thy housekeeping,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Hath won the greatest favour of the commons,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Excepting none but good Duke Humphrey:
speaker: SALISBURY

string: And, brother York, thy acts in Ireland,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: In bringing them to civil discipline,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Thy late exploits done in the heart of France,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: When thou wert regent for our sovereign,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Have made thee fear'd and honour'd of the people:
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Join we together, for the public good,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: In what we can, to bridle and suppress
speaker: SALISBURY

string: The pride of Suffolk and the cardinal,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: With Somerset's and Buckingham's ambition;
speaker: SALISBURY

string: And, as we may, cherish Duke Humphrey's deeds,
speaker: SALISBURY

string: While they do tend the profit of the land.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: WARWICK
speaker: WARWICK

string: So God help Warwick, as he loves the land,
speaker: WARWICK

string: And common profit of his country!
speaker: WARWICK

string: YORK
speaker: YORK

string: [Aside]  And so says York, for he hath greatest cause.
speaker: YORK

string: SALISBURY
speaker: SALISBURY

string: Then let's make haste away, and look unto the main.
speaker: SALISBURY

string: WARWICK
speaker: WARWICK

string: Unto the main! O father, Maine is lost;
speaker: WARWICK

string: That Maine which by main force Warwick did win,
speaker: WARWICK

string: And would have kept so long as breath did last!
speaker: WARWICK

string: Main chance, father, you meant; but I meant Maine,
speaker: WARWICK

string: Which I will win from France, or else be slain,
speaker: WARWICK

string: Exeunt WARWICK and SALISBURY
YORK
speaker: YORK

string: Anjou and Maine are given to the French;
speaker: YORK

string: Paris is lost; the state of Normandy
speaker: YORK

string: Stands on a tickle point, now they are gone:
speaker: YORK

string: Suffolk concluded on the articles,
speaker: YORK

string: The peers agreed, and Henry was well pleased
speaker: YORK

string: To change two dukedoms for a duke's fair daughter.
speaker: YORK

string: I cannot blame them all: what is't to them?
speaker: YORK

string: 'Tis thine they give away, and not their own.
speaker: YORK

string: Pirates may make cheap pennyworths of their pillage
speaker: YORK

string: And purchase friends and give to courtezans,
speaker: YORK

string: Still revelling like lords till all be gone;
speaker: YORK

string: While as the silly owner of the goods
speaker: YORK

string: Weeps over them and wrings his hapless hands
speaker: YORK

string: And shakes his head and trembling stands aloof,
speaker: YORK

string: While all is shared and all is borne away,
speaker: YORK

string: Ready to starve and dare not touch his own:
speaker: YORK

string: So York must sit and fret and bite his tongue,
speaker: YORK

string: While his own lands are bargain'd for and sold.
speaker: YORK

string: Methinks the realms of England, France and Ireland
speaker: YORK

string: Bear that proportion to my flesh and blood
speaker: YORK

string: As did the fatal brand Althaea burn'd
speaker: YORK

string: Unto the prince's heart of Calydon.
speaker: YORK

string: Anjou and Maine both given unto the French!
speaker: YORK

string: Cold news for me, for I had hope of France,
speaker: YORK

string: Even as I have of fertile England's soil.
speaker: YORK

string: A day will come when York shall claim his own;
speaker: YORK

string: And therefore I will take the Nevils' parts
speaker: YORK

string: And make a show of love to proud Duke Humphrey,
speaker: YORK

string: And, when I spy advantage, claim the crown,
speaker: YORK

string: For that's the golden mark I seek to hit:
speaker: YORK

string: Nor shall proud Lancaster usurp my right,
speaker: YORK

string: Nor hold the sceptre in his childish fist,
speaker: YORK

string: Nor wear the diadem upon his head,
speaker: YORK

string: Whose church-like humours fits not for a crown.
speaker: YORK

string: Then, York, be still awhile, till time do serve:
speaker: YORK

string: Watch thou and wake when others be asleep,
speaker: YORK

string: To pry into the secrets of the state;
speaker: YORK

string: Till Henry, surfeiting in joys of love,
speaker: YORK

string: With his new bride and England's dear-bought queen,
speaker: YORK

string: And Humphrey with the peers be fall'n at jars:
speaker: YORK

string: Then will I raise aloft the milk-white rose,
speaker: YORK

string: With whose sweet smell the air shall be perfumed;
speaker: YORK

string: And in my standard bear the arms of York
speaker: YORK

string: To grapple with the house of Lancaster;
speaker: YORK

string: And, force perforce, I'll make him yield the crown,
speaker: YORK

string: Whose bookish rule hath pull'd fair England down.
speaker: YORK

string: Exit
SCENE II. GLOUCESTER'S house.
Enter GLOUCESTER and his DUCHESS
DUCHESS
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Why droops my lord, like over-ripen'd corn,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Hanging the head at Ceres' plenteous load?
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Why doth the great Duke Humphrey knit his brows,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: As frowning at the favours of the world?
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Why are thine eyes fixed to the sullen earth,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Gazing on that which seems to dim thy sight?
speaker: DUCHESS

string: What seest thou there? King Henry's diadem,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Enchased with all the honours of the world?
speaker: DUCHESS

string: If so, gaze on, and grovel on thy face,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Until thy head be circled with the same.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Put forth thy hand, reach at the glorious gold.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: What, is't too short? I'll lengthen it with mine:
speaker: DUCHESS

string: And, having both together heaved it up,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: We'll both together lift our heads to heaven,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: And never more abase our sight so low
speaker: DUCHESS

string: As to vouchsafe one glance unto the ground.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: O Nell, sweet Nell, if thou dost love thy lord,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Banish the canker of ambitious thoughts.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And may that thought, when I imagine ill
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Against my king and nephew, virtuous Henry,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Be my last breathing in this mortal world!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: My troublous dream this night doth make me sad.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: DUCHESS
speaker: DUCHESS

string: What dream'd my lord? tell me, and I'll requite it
speaker: DUCHESS

string: With sweet rehearsal of my morning's dream.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Methought this staff, mine office-badge in court,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Was broke in twain; by whom I have forgot,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: But, as I think, it was by the cardinal;
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And on the pieces of the broken wand
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Were placed the heads of Edmund Duke of Somerset,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And William de la Pole, first duke of Suffolk.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: This was my dream: what it doth bode, God knows.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: DUCHESS
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Tut, this was nothing but an argument
speaker: DUCHESS

string: That he that breaks a stick of Gloucester's grove
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Shall lose his head for his presumption.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: But list to me, my Humphrey, my sweet duke:
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Methought I sat in seat of majesty
speaker: DUCHESS

string: In the cathedral church of Westminster,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: And in that chair where kings and queens are crown'd;
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Where Henry and dame Margaret kneel'd to me
speaker: DUCHESS

string: And on my head did set the diadem.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Nay, Eleanor, then must I chide outright:
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Presumptuous dame, ill-nurtured Eleanor,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Art thou not second woman in the realm,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And the protector's wife, beloved of him?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Hast thou not worldly pleasure at command,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Above the reach or compass of thy thought?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: And wilt thou still be hammering treachery,
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: To tumble down thy husband and thyself
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: From top of honour to disgrace's feet?
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Away from me, and let me hear no more!
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: DUCHESS
speaker: DUCHESS

string: What, what, my lord! are you so choleric
speaker: DUCHESS

string: With Eleanor, for telling but her dream?
speaker: DUCHESS

string: Next time I'll keep my dreams unto myself,
speaker: DUCHESS

string: And not be cheque'd.
speaker: DUCHESS

string: GLOUCESTER
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Nay, be not angry; I am pleased again.
speaker: GLOUCESTER

string: Enter Messenger
